description:
Hi folks! Perhaps a bit of an odd post but wanted to reach out to get some feedback from the Rust fellows in the community. I’m writing a toy work pool/supervisor library, poolparty, inspired by Erlang’s poolboy. Everything is effectively a back-of-the-napkin sketch but have some areas I’d like some guidance with.

We have a concept of a Worker trait that library-users can implement to encapsulate some workload (e.g., perform inference against some dataset).

pub trait Workable: Debug + Send + Sync + Sized {
    type Task: Task + Debug;
    type Output: Debug + Send;
    type Error: Debug + Send;

    fn process(task: Self::Task) -> impl Future<Output = Response<Self>>;
}

As a library, I’d like to hide away all the state-machinery and the running of the worker. Specifically how it receives messages from the supervisor, changes state, propagates results and handles errors (outside of the task context).

After reading a few posts on state-machines in Rust, some more complex than others, there are a few requirements I had:

  • State transitions do not need to be checked at compile-time
  • Transitions may need to accept event inputs (e.g., a Task to run)
  • Transitions should not block the task, as we still need to be able to receive events from the supervisor during a long transition (e.g., while running a task, we receive a cancel event) and must gracefully cancel and transition to idle.

The idea I have so far is a simple State enum that is packed into the Worker struct, which is a wrapper struct around the Workable trait.

#[derive(Debug)]
enum State<W: Workable> {
    Idle,
    Running { task: W::Task },
    Error(W::Error),
    Stop,
}

Worker struct containing the state.

pub struct Worker<'a, W: Workable> {
    id: usize,
    rx: Receiver<Request<W>>,
    state: State<W>,
    worker: PhantomData<&'a W>, // Ignore
}

And implementing the state transitions by implementing the State enum on the generic Worker<W>.

impl<W: Workable> State<W> {
    // NOTE(jdb): The following is the initial state machine for workers.
    //
    //                           complete/success
    //                           cancel
    //              ┌───────────────────────────────┐
    //              │                               │
    //         ┌────▼─────┐                   ┌─────┴─────┐
    //       ┌─┤          │      task         │           │
    // cancel│ │   IDLE   ├───────────────────►  RUNNING  │
    //       └─►          │                   │           │
    //         └────┬─────┘                   └───┬─┬─────┘
    //              │            shutdown         │ │
    //      shutdown│ ┌───────────────────────────┘ │complete/fail
    //              │ │                             │
    //         ┌────▼─▼───┐                   ┌─────▼─────┐
    //         │          │      shutdown     │           │
    //         │   STOP   ◄───────────────────┤   ERROR   │
    //         │          │                   │           │
    //         └──────────┘                   └───────────┘
    //
    //  Note that retrying should not be handled by the worker. Instead it
    //  is the job of the Supervisor to determine if we should shut down
    //  the worker, and spawn a new one with the same task. This is done to
    //  ensure that we are able to capture error state before terminating a
    //  worker.
    fn next(&self, event: Request<W>) -> Result<State<W>, String> {
        match (self, event) {
            (State::Idle, Request::Task(t)) => Ok(State::Running { task: t }),
            (State::Idle, Request::Cancel) => Ok(State::Idle),
            (State::Running { task: _ }, Request::Cancel) => Ok(State::Idle),
            (_, Request::Shutdown) => Ok(State::Stop),
            _ => Err("invalid transition".to_string()),
        }
    }
}

This part seems okay. My issues are that:

  1. I cannot take ownership of the Worker struct as part of the state transition. This leads to this weird case where we need a &mut self to update state.
  2. handle_event cannot return the transitioned state. That said, this might be overcome with a macro.

And likely a large number of other anti-patterns. Happy to hear any feedback or guidance on how to improve this!
